qas.question: When was the Baird system discontinued?
What prevented France's 819-line system from achieving the definition it was capable of?

answers.text: the technical limitations of the time

qas.question: Which system used interlaced scanning to correct the flicker problem of the 240-line?
When was the Baird system created?
What prevented France's 919-line system from achieving the definition it was capable of?
Which system used interlaced scanning to correct the flicker problem of the 940-line?

context: <a0_0>The <b5_0>British high-definition<b5_0/> TV service<a0_0/> started trials in August 1936 and a regular service on 2 November 1936 using both the (mechanical) Baird 240 line sequential scan (later to be inaccurately rechristened 'progressive') and the (electronic) Marconi-EMI 405 line interlaced systems. The Baird system was discontinued in <a1_0><b6_0>February 1937<b6_0/><a1_0/>. In 1938 <a2_0><b7_0>France<b7_0/><a2_0/> followed with their own 441-line system, variants of which were also used by a number of other countries. The US NTSC 525-line system joined in 1941. In 1949 France introduced an even higher-resolution standard at 819 lines, a system that should have been high definition even by today's standards, but was monochrome only and <a3_0>the <b8_0>technical limitations of the time<b8_0/><a3_0/> prevented it from achieving the definition of which it should have been capable. All of these systems used interlacing and a 4:3 aspect ratio except the 240-line system which was progressive (actually described at the time by the technically correct term "sequential") and the 405-line system which started as 5:4 and later changed to 4:3. The <a4_0><b9_0>405-line<b9_0/> system<a4_0/> adopted the (at that time) revolutionary idea of interlaced scanning to overcome the flicker problem of the 240-line with its 25 Hz frame rate. The 240-line system could have doubled its frame rate but this would have meant that the transmitted signal would have doubled in bandwidth, an unacceptable option as the video baseband bandwidth was required to be not more than 3 MHz.
